content:
MouseDevice Class

Definition

Represents a mouse device.

In this Article

public abstract class MouseDevice : System.Windows.Input.InputDevice
Inheritance
Object
DispatcherObject
System.Windows.Input.InputDevice
MouseDevice

Inherited Members

Equals(Object)
Equals(Object,Object)
GetHashCode()
GetType()
MemberwiseClone()
ReferenceEquals(Object,Object)
ToString()
CheckAccess()
Dispatcher
VerifyAccess()

Remarks

The MouseDevice supports the Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.

For mouse related input, use the Mouse class. The Mouse class represents the mouse to an application and provides methods, properties, and events that reflect the state of the mouse.

Properties

ActiveSource

Gets the PresentationSource that is reporting input for this device.

public override System.Windows.PresentationSource ActiveSource { get; }
Value
PresentationSource

The source of input for this device.

Captured

Gets the IInputElement that is captured by the mouse.

public System.Windows.IInputElement Captured { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element which is captured by the mouse.

Remarks

When an element captures the mouse, it receives mouse input whether or not the cursor is within its borders.

DirectlyOver

Gets the element that the mouse pointer is directly over.

public System.Windows.IInputElement DirectlyOver { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element the mouse pointer is over.

Remarks

The mouse is considered directly over an element if the mouse has been captured to that element.

Controls can be composed of multiple elements. DirectlyOver reports the specific element in the composite control the mouse pointer is over and not the control itself. For example, depending on which part of a Button the pointer is over, the DirectlyOver property could report the TextBox of the Content property or the ButtonChrome.

Use the IsMouseOver property on UIElement and ContentElement to determine whether the mouse is over an element, which includes its visual child elements or control compositing elements.

LeftButton

Gets the state of the left mouse button of this mouse device.

public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState LeftButton { get; }
Value
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

MiddleButton

The state of the middle button of this mouse device.

public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState MiddleButton { get; }
Value
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

OverrideCursor

Gets or sets the cursor for the entire application.

public System.Windows.Input.Cursor OverrideCursor { get; set; }
Value
Cursor

The override cursor or null if OverrideCursor is not set.

Remarks

The Cursor that OverrideCursor is set to will be applied to the whole application.

To clear the override Cursor, set OverrideCursor to null.

Setting OverrideCursor to None will force the mouse cursor not to be displayed, but mouse events are still processed.

RightButton

Gets the state of the right button of this mouse device.

public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState RightButton { get; }
Value
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

Target

Gets the IInputElement that the input from this mouse device is sent to.

public override System.Windows.IInputElement Target { get; }
Value
IInputElement

The element that receives the input.

Remarks

The target for a MouseDevice is the object the mouse is over or the object with mouse capture.

XButton1

Gets the state of the first extended button on this mouse device.

public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState XButton1 { get; }
Value
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

XButton2

Gets the state of the second extended button of this mouse device.

public System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState XButton2 { get; }
Value
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

Methods

Capture(IInputElement)

Captures mouse events to the specified element.

public bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element);
element
IInputElement

The element to capture the mouse.

Returns
Boolean

true if the element was able to capture the mouse; otherwise, false.

Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

element is not a UIElement or ContentElement.

Remarks

When an element captures the mouse, it receives mouse input whether the cursor is within its borders

If a CaptureMode is not specified, the default CaptureMode is CaptureMode.

To release mouse capture, call Capture passing null as the element to capture.

If the mouse is captured when a <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> or <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseUp> event is raised and the input is not going to the element underneath the mouse, <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseDownOutsideCapturedElement> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseUpOutsideCapturedElement> are raised first. This enables the captured element a chance to release capture before the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseUp> events are routed.

Capture(IInputElement,CaptureMode)

Captures mouse input to the specified element using the specified CaptureMode.

public bool Capture (System.Windows.IInputElement element, System.Windows.Input.CaptureMode captureMode);
element
IInputElement

The element to capture the mouse..

captureMode
CaptureMode

The capture policy to use.

Returns
Boolean

true if the element was able to capture the mouse; otherwise, false.

Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

element is not a UIElement or ContentElement.

InvalidEnumArgumentException

captureMode is not a valid CaptureMode.

Remarks

When an element captures the mouse, it receives mouse input whether or not the cursor is within its borders.

To release mouse capture, call Capture passing null as the element to capture.

If the mouse is captured when a <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> or <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseUp> event is raised and the input is not going to the element underneath the mouse, <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseDownOutsideCapturedElement> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.PreviewMouseUpOutsideCapturedElement> are raised first. This enables the captured element a chance to release capture before the <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseDown> and <xref:System.Windows.Input.Mouse.MouseUp> events are routed.

GetButtonState(MouseButton)

Gets the state of the specified mouse button.

protected System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonState GetButtonState (System.Windows.Input.MouseButton mouseButton);
mouseButton
MouseButton

The button which is being queried.

Returns
MouseButtonState

The state of the button.

GetClientPosition()

Calculates the position of the mouse pointer, in client coordinates.

protected System.Windows.Point GetClientPosition ();
Returns
Point

The position of the mouse pointer, in client coordinates.

GetClientPosition(PresentationSource)

Calculates the position of the mouse pointer, in client coordinates, in the specified PresentationSource.

protected System.Windows.Point GetClientPosition (System.Windows.PresentationSource presentationSource);
presentationSource
PresentationSource

The source in which to obtain the mouse position.

Returns
Point

The position of the mouse pointer, in client coordinates, in the specified PresentationSource.

GetPosition(IInputElement)

Gets the position of the mouse relative to a specified element.

public System.Windows.Point GetPosition (System.Windows.IInputElement relativeTo);
relativeTo
IInputElement

The frame of reference in which to calculate the position of the mouse.

Returns
Point

The position of the mouse relative to the parameter relativeTo.

Exceptions
InvalidOperationException

relativeTo is null or is not a UIElement or ContentElement.

Remarks

The position of the mouse pointer is calculated relative to the specified IInputElement with the upper-left corner of element being the point of origin, 0,0.

GetScreenPosition()

Calculates the screen position of the mouse pointer.

protected System.Windows.Point GetScreenPosition ();
Returns
Point

The position of the mouse pointer.

SetCursor(Cursor)

Sets the mouse pointer to the specified Cursor

public bool SetCursor (System.Windows.Input.Cursor cursor);
cursor
Cursor

The cursor to set the mouse pointer to.

Returns
Boolean

true if the mouse cursor is set; otherwise, false.

Remarks

Note that this cursor does not apply any particular UIElement, but rather it applies to the whole application.

Synchronize()

Forces the mouse to resynchronize.

public void Synchronize ();

Remarks

The MouseDevice monitors layout changes and calls Synchronize. There are cases in which the mouse input system must be forced to update for it to respond to changes. For example, you must resynchronize the mouse on a timer.

UpdateCursor()

Forces the mouse cursor to update.

public void UpdateCursor ();
